content.raw:
Oh, man I like this branch.  :-)  I've run all day so far with the changed val-gazebo debian and have seen no side effects from it.

But with this pr applied on top of r689 (along with the filtering branch), I have one problem, and notice one anomaly (which has not yet caused any trouble).

The problem relates to the new harness logic, and standing pressure:  #!/osrf/srcsim/issues/210/harness-after-advancing-checkpoint-can

The anomaly is that I will see the left knee quiver on pivots.  The turns complete, but I don't normally see that quiver.  I know others have reported the quiver as a key indicator of trouble, so I figured I'd mention it.  Unfortunately, the new filtering branch (which I absolutely love), makes the replays a bit more choppy, so it's not very easy to show off the quiver in a replay (or look for it in other branches).

If nothing else, this branch is extremely valuable for development - it feels like the robot is flying!
content.html:
Oh, man I like this branch. :-) I've run all day so far with the changed val-gazebo debian and have seen no side effects from it.

But with this pr applied on top of r689 (along with the filtering branch), I have one problem, and notice one anomaly (which has not yet caused any trouble).

The problem relates to the new harness logic, and standing pressure: #!/osrf/srcsim/issues/210/harness-after-advancing-checkpoint-can

The anomaly is that I will see the left knee quiver on pivots. The turns complete, but I don't normally see that quiver. I know others have reported the quiver as a key indicator of trouble, so I figured I'd mention it. Unfortunately, the new filtering branch (which I absolutely love), makes the replays a bit more choppy, so it's not very easy to show off the quiver in a replay (or look for it in other branches).

If nothing else, this branch is extremely valuable for development - it feels like the robot is flying!
